column4: I seem to be having troubles with my Ubuntu version.  I should be running 10.04, but menu.lst says "Ubuntu 7.10, kernel 2.6.32-23-generic" even after running update-grub. Also, when I try to reload package information, it's trying to find Packages.gz in main, universe, restricted, and multiverse, for gutsy (not lucid).
Opening "About Ubuntu" from the System menu informs me that I am "using Ubuntu 10.04 LTS".
Because it never prompted me to, and continued using grub1. So I did.
edit 3rd party sources and change "gutsy" for "lucid"
Is that in the "Other Software" tab of Software Sources?
There are no third-party sources that say "gutsy" - they all say "lucid" or "lucid-security", etc.
One of them said "stable", so I disabled it, but when reloading it's still looking for gutsy packages.
look at those repos and if they say gutsy select them click "edit" and change gutsy for lucid
Yes, I did that.  Every single checked repository did not say "gutsy".
just to make sure, have your rebooted after the upgrade?
I upgraded quite some time ago.  But I haven't rebooted since changing sources.list.  I'll try that now.
ikonia: update-grub is still titling my ubuntu release as 7.10... anyway, rebooting; brb.
ikonia: Update Manager still says my release is no longer supported, after rebooting.
I don't remember exactly what my upgrade path was before 9.10.
